#Text=STORY OF THE PIG AND THE BILLY-GOAT
#Text=Every hour or so Mr Button would shake his lethargy off , and rise and look round for “ sea-gulls , ” but the prospect was sail-less as the prehistoric sea , wingless , voiceless .
#Text=When Dick would fret now and then , the old sailor would always devise some means of amusing him .

#Text=He made him fishing-tackle out of a bent pin and some small twine that happened to be in the boat , and told him to fish for “ pinkeens ” ; and Dick , with the pathetic faith of childhood , fished .
#Text=Then he told them things .
#Text=He had spent a year at Deal long ago , where a cousin of his was married to a boatman .

#Text=Mr Button had put in a year as a longshoreman at Deal , and he had got a great lot to tell of his cousin and her husband , and more especially of one , Hannah ; Hannah was his cousin ’s baby — a most marvellous child , who was born with its “ buck ” teeth fully developed , and whose first unnatural act on entering the world was to make a snap at the “ docther . ”
#Text=“ Hung on to his fist like a bull-dog , and him bawlin ’ ‘ Murther ! ’ ”
#Text=“ Mrs James , ” said Emmeline , referring to a Boston acquaintance , “ had a little baby , and it was pink . ”
#Text=“ Ay , ay , ” said Paddy ;
#Text=“ they ’re mostly pink to start with , but they fade whin they ’re washed . ”
#Text=“ It ’d no teeth , ” said Emmeline , “ for I put my finger in to see . ”

#Text=“ The doctor brought it in a bag , ” put in Dick , who was still steadily fishing — “ dug it out of a cabbage patch ; an ’ I got a trow’l and dug all our cabbage patch up , but there were n’t any babies — but there were no end of worms . ”
#Text=“ I wish I had a baby , ” said Emmeline , “ and I would n’t send it back to the cabbage patch . ”
#Text=“ The doctor , ” explained Dick , “ took it back and planted it again ; and Mrs James cried when I asked her , and daddy said it was put back to grow and turn into an angel . ”
#Text=“ Angels have wings , ” said Emmeline dreamily .
#Text=“ And , ” pursued Dick , “ I told cook , and she said to Jane , daddy was always stuffing children up with — something or ’ nother .
#Text=And I asked daddy to let me see him stuffing up a child — and daddy said cook ’d have to go away for saying that , and she went away next day . ”
#Text=“ She had three big trunks and a box for her bonnet , ” said Emmeline , with a far-away look as she recalled the incident .
#Text=“ And the cabman asked her had n’t she any more trunks to put on his cab , and had n’t she forgot the parrot cage , ” said Dick .
#Text=“ I wish I had a parrot in a cage , ” murmured Emmeline , moving slightly so as to get more in the shadow of the sail .
#Text=“ And what in the world would you be doin ’ with a par’t in a cage ? ” asked Mr Button .
#Text=“ I ’d let it out , ” replied Emmeline .
#Text=“ Spakin ’ about lettin ’ par’ts out of cages , I remimber me grandfather had an ould pig , ” said Paddy ( they were all talking seriously together like equals ) .

#Text=“ I was a spalpeen no bigger than the height of me knee , and I ’d go to the sty door , and he ’d come to the door , and grunt an ’ blow wid his nose undher it ; an ’ I ’d grunt back to vex him , an ’ hammer wid me fist on it , an ’ shout ‘ Halloo there !
#Text=halloo there ! ’
#Text=and ‘ Halloo to you ! ’ he ’d say , spakin ’ the pigs ’ language .
#Text=‘ Let me out , ’ he ’d say , ‘ and I ’ll give yiz a silver shilling . ’
#Text=“ ‘ Pass it under the door , ’ I ’d answer him .
#Text=Thin he ’d stick the snout of him undher the door an ’ I ’d hit it a clip with a stick , and he ’d yell murther Irish .
#Text=An ’ me mother ’d come out an ’ baste me , an ’ well I desarved it .

#Text=“ Well , wan day I opened the sty door , an ’ out he boulted and away and beyant , over hill and hollo he goes till he gets to the edge of the cliff overlookin ’ the say , and there he meets a billy-goat , and he and the billy-goat has a division of opinion .
#Text=“ ‘ Away wid yiz ! ’ says the billy-goat .
#Text=“
#Text=‘ Away wid yourself ! ’ says he .
#Text=“
#Text=‘ Whose you talkin ’ to ? ’ says t’other .
#Text=“ ‘ Yourself , ’ says him .
#Text=“
#Text=‘ Who stole the eggs ? ’ says the billy-goat .
#Text=“
#Text=‘ Ax your ould grandmother ! ’ says the pig .
#Text=“ ‘ Ax me ould which mother ? ’ says the billy-goat .
#Text=“
#Text=‘ Oh , ax me — — ’
#Text=And before he could complete the sintence ram , blam , the ould billy-goat butts him in the chist , and away goes the both of thim whirtlin ’ into the say below .

#Text=“ Thin me ould grandfather comes out , and collars me by the scruff , and ‘ Into the sty with you ! ’ says he ; and into the sty I wint , and there they kep ’ me for a fortni’t on bran mash and skim milk — and well I desarved it . ”

#Text=They dined somewhere about eleven o’clock , and at noon Paddy unstepped the mast and made a sort of little tent or awning with the sail in the bow of the boat to protect the children from the rays of the vertical sun .

#Text=Then he took his place in the bottom of the boat , in the stern , stuck Dick ’s straw hat over his face to preserve it from the sun , kicked about a bit to get a comfortable position , and fell asleep .
#Text=CHAPTER VIII
#Text=“ S-H-E-N-A-N-D-O-A-H ”
#Text=He had slept an hour and more when he was brought to his senses by a thin and prolonged shriek .
#Text=It was Emmeline in a nightmare , or more properly a day-mare , brought on by a meal of sardines and the haunting memory of the gibbly-gobbly-ums .
#Text=When she was shaken ( it always took a considerable time to bring her to , from these seizures ) and comforted , the mast was restepped .
